overview: How to work out and pay your Council Tax bill, exemptions, rules for full-time students, second homes, empty properties, problems paying and financial help
title: Council Tax

table.body:
You’ll need to know 3 things: 

s1. The [valuation band for your home](http://www.voa.gov.uk/cti/InitS.asp?lcn=0 "Find the valuation band for your home"){:rel="external"}
s2. How much your [local council](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Find your local council"){:rel="external"} charges for that band
s3. Whether you can get a discount or [exemption](/council-tax/council-tax-exemptions "Council Tax exemptions") from the full bill - for example, people living on their own get a 25% discount

Find out if you're eligible and [apply for a Council Tax discount](/apply-for-council-tax-discount "Apply for a Council Tax discount").

^A full Council Tax bill is based on 2 or more adults living in a household.^

If you think your home is in the wrong valuation band, you may be able to [challenge your Council Tax band](/council-tax-appeals/challenge-your-band "Council Tax appeals: challenge your band").

In England and [Scotland,](http://www.scotland.gov.uk/library3/localgov/ctvb-00.asp "Scottish Council Tax Bands"){:rel="external"} valuation bands are based on property values on 1 April 1991, not what a property is worth today. In Wales, valuation bands are based on property values on 1 April 2003.

$D
[Download the Valuation Office Agency’s ‘Understanding your Council Tax banding’ (PDF, 351KB)](http://www.voa.gov.uk/corporate/_downloads/pdf/VO7858_understanding_ct.pdf "Understanding your Council Tax banding"){:rel="external"}

$D

If you're having trouble paying your bill, you may be able to get [financial help](/council-tax/problems-paying-and-financial-help "Council Tax: problems paying and financial help").
table.title: Working out your Council Tax

table.body:
If you're 18 or over and own or rent a home, you'll usually have to pay Council Tax. Spouses and partners who live together are jointly responsible for paying the bill.

If you're unsure about who's responsible for paying, [contact your local council.](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1/ “Find your local council”){:rel="external"}

##When payments are due
Your Council Tax bill tells you:

- how much you have to pay for the year
- how that amount has been worked out
- the dates you have to pay

The cost is usually split into 10 monthly payments.

If the amount of Council Tax you have to pay changes during the year, you’ll get a new bill.

##Ways to pay
Some councils let you [pay your Council Tax online](/pay-council-tax "Pay your Council Tax online") or over the phone.

You can usually also pay:

- by post
- by direct debit
- by standing order
- in person at your council's offices
- using 'Paypoint', 'Payzone' or 'Quickcards' for cash payments at post offices, banks, newsagents and convenience stores
table.title: Paying the bill

table.body:
A full Council Tax bill is based on at least 2 adults living in a home. 

If you count as an adult for Council Tax and live on your own, you'll get 25% off your bill.

You'll also get a discount if you live with people who don't count as adults for Council Tax.

^[Apply for a Council Tax discount](/apply-for-council-tax-discount "Apply for a council tax discount").^

##Who doesn't count?
These people are **not** counted as adults for Council Tax:

- children under 18
- people on apprentice schemes
- 18 and 19-year-olds in full-time education
- [full-time college and university students](/council-tax/full-time-students "Students")
- young people under 25 who get funding from the Skills Funding Agency or Young People’s Learning Agency
- student nurses
- foreign language assistants registered with the British Council
- people with a severe mental [disability](/council-tax/discounts-for-disabled-people "disability")
- live-in carers who look after someone who isn't their partner, spouse or child
- diplomats

To work out if you should get a Council Tax discount:

s1. Count the number of adults who live in your home as their main home
s2. Discount anyone in the list above
s3. If you're left with 1 person who counts as an adult, your Council Tax bill will be reduced by 25%
s4. If you’re left with no-one who counts as an adult, your bill will be reduced by 50%


##Your bill doesn’t show a discount
If there's no discount listed and you think you should get one, write to [your council.](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1 "Find your local council"){:rel="external"}

The council has 2 months to respond. If you disagree with the council's decision or don't hear back within this time, you can [appeal to the Valuation Tribunal.](http://www.valuationtribunal.gov.uk/A1Form.aspx "Appeal to the Valuation Tribunal"){:rel="external"}

##You get a Council Tax discount by mistake
You must tell your council. If you don’t, you could get a fine.

The council may also ask you to pay back the discount.
table.title: Council Tax exemptions

table.body:
Households where everyone's a full-time student don't have to pay Council Tax. If you do get a bill, you can [apply for an exemption](/apply-for-council-tax-discount "Apply for a Council Tax exemption").

To count as a full-time student, your course must:

+ last at least 1 year
+ involve at least 21 hours study per week

If you study for a qualification up to A level and you’re under 20, your course must:

+ last at least 3 months
+ involve at least 12 hours study per week

If there's someone in your household who's not a full-time student, you will get a Council Tax bill. But your household might still qualify for a [discount](/council-tax/council-tax-exemptions "Single person's discount").
table.title: Full-time students

table.body:
##Disabled band reduction scheme##

This scheme makes sure disabled people don't pay more Council Tax if they need:

+ a bigger property 
+ to adapt their home because of their disability

The property must be the main home of at least 1 disabled person. They can be an adult or a child and don't have to be responsible for paying the Council Tax.  

The property must have 1 or more of:

- an extra bathroom, kitchen or other room for the disabled person
- extra space inside the property for using a wheelchair

##Other Council Tax reductions##

People who are severely mentally impaired and some live-in carers [are exempt](/council-tax/council-tax-exemptions "Council tax exemptions") when working out Council Tax. 

You can [apply for a Council Tax discount](/apply-for-council-tax-discount "Apply for a Council Tax discount") from your local council.
table.title: Discounts for disabled people

table.body:
##Second homes
You may pay less Council Tax for a property you own or rent that's not your main home.

Councils can give furnished second homes or holiday homes a discount of between 10% and 50%.

##Empty properties
There's no Council Tax to pay on empty and unfurnished homes for up to 6 months. After this, they may qualify for a discount of up to 50%, depending on the council.

If the owner of a house has died, Council Tax isn't charged for up to 6 months after probate is granted (your legal right to sell the home).

Some homes don't get a Council Tax bill for as long as they stay empty. They include homes:

- of someone in prison (except for not paying a fine or Council Tax)
- of someone who's moved into a care home or hospital
- that have been repossessed
- that cannot be lived in by law
- that are empty because they've been compulsory purchased and will be demolished

Homes undergoing major repair work or structural changes (like rebuilding walls and floors) don't get a Council Tax bill for up to 12 months.

##Completion notices
Local councils usually send completion notices to new homes and properties that have had major home improvements. A completion notice tells you the day the council thinks your property was finished. 

You have to start paying Council Tax from this date.
table.title: Second homes and empty properties

table.body:
Tell [your council](http://local.direct.gov.uk/LDGRedirect/Start.do?mode=1/ "Contact your local council"){:rel="external"} as soon as you think you’ll have a problem paying your Council Tax bill. 

Your council might let you spread your payments over a longer period, for example 12 months instead of 10.

Or, if you're really struggling to pay, your council may be able to give you a one-off discount.

##Council Tax Benefit and Second Adult Rebate
You may be able to claim [Council Tax Benefit](/council-tax-benefit "Council Tax Benefit") or Second Adult Rebate if:

- you're on a low income 
- you live with another adult (not your partner) who's on a low income

##Missing Council Tax payments
You Council Tax is split into 10 monthly payments.

If you haven’t spoken to your council about a problem paying your bill, and you miss a payment, your council will ask you for payment:

s1. Your council will send you a **reminder notice** giving you 7 days to pay.
s2. If you don't pay within 7 days, the council will send you a **final notice**. You'll also get a final notice if your monthly Council Tax payments are late 3 times in a year. The final notice gives you 7 days to pay the full amount of Council Tax for the whole year.
s3. If you don’t pay the final notice within 7 days, the council will take **legal action** to get the Council Tax you owe. The court may also make you pay the council’s costs, like hiring a lawyer.
